query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 O poca nostra nobiltà di sangue, 2 se glorïar di te la gente fai 3 qua giù dove l’affetto nostro langue,
query.result: 1 Oh, our nobility of blood, how little, 2 if you make people glorify you down here 3 where our affection languishes,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
4 mirabil cosa non mi sarà mai: 5 ché là dove appetito non si torce, 6 dico nel cielo, io me ne gloriai.
query.result: 4 it will never be a wondrous thing to me: 5 because up there where desire is not twisted, 6 I mean in Heaven, I did glorify myself in it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
7 Ben se’ tu manto che tosto raccorce: 8 sì che, se non s’appon di dì in die, 9 lo tempo va dintorno con le force.
query.result: 7 You are indeed a cloak that quickly shortens: 8 so that, if it is not lengthened day by day, 9 time goes around with its shears.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
10 Dal ‘voi’ che prima a Roma s’offerie, 11 in che la sua famiglia men persevra, 12 ricominciaron le parole mie;

Please translate each line literally into English.
13 onde Beatrice, ch’era un poco scevra, 14 ridendo, parve quella che tossio 15 al primo fallo scritto di Ginevra.
query.result: 13 whereupon Beatrice, who was a little withdrawn, 14 laughing, seemed like the one who coughed 15 at the first written fault of Guinevere.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 Per tanti rivi s’empie d’allegrezza 20 la mente mia, che di sé fa letizia 21 perché può sostener che non si spezza.
query.result: 19 Through so many streams my mind is filled with gladness, 20 that it makes joy of itself 21 because it can endure without breaking.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Ditemi dunque, cara mia primizia, 23 quai fuor li vostri antichi e quai fuor li anni 24 che si segnaro in vostra püerizia;

Please translate each line literally into English.
25 ditemi de l’ovil di San Giovanni 26 quanto era allora, e chi eran le genti 27 tra esso degne di più alti scanni».
query.result: 25 tell me about the sheepfold of Saint John, 26 how large it was then, and who were the people 27 among them worthy of the highest seats.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Come s’avviva a lo spirar d’i venti 29 carbone in fiamma, così vid’ io quella 30 luce risplendere a’ miei blandimenti;

Please translate each line literally into English.
31 e come a li occhi miei si fé più bella, 32 così con voce più dolce e soave, 33 ma non con questa moderna favella,
query.result: 31 and as it grew fairer to my eyes, 32 so with a voice more sweet and gentle, 33 but not with this modern speech,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 dissemi: «Da quel dì che fu detto ‘Ave’ 35 al parto in che mia madre, ch’è or santa, 36 s’allevïò di me ond’ era grave,
query.result: 34 it said to me: "From that day when 'Hail' was spoken 35 to the birth in which my mother, who is now holy, 36 was relieved of me with whom she was heavy,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 al suo Leon cinquecento cinquanta 38 e trenta fiate venne questo foco 39 a rinfiammarsi sotto la sua pianta.
query.result: 37 this fire has come to rekindle itself under its paw 38 five hundred and fifty times and thirty 39 since its birth under the constellation of Leo.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Li antichi miei e io nacqui nel loco 41 dove si truova pria l’ultimo sesto 42 da quei che corre il vostro annüal gioco.
query.result: 40 My ancestors and I were born in the place 41 where the last sixth is first found 42 by those who run your annual race.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
43 Basti d’i miei maggiori udirne questo: 44 chi ei si fosser e onde venner quivi, 45 più è tacer che ragionare onesto.
query.result: 43 Let it suffice to hear this much about my ancestors: 44 who they were and whence they came here, 45 it is more seemly to be silent than to speak.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 Tutti color ch’a quel tempo eran ivi 47 da poter arme tra Marte e ’l Batista, 48 eran il quinto di quei ch’or son vivi.
query.result: 46 All those who at that time were there 47 of an age to bear arms between Mars and the Baptist, 48 were a fifth of those who are alive now.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Ma la cittadinanza, ch’è or mista 50 di Campi, di Certaldo e di Fegghine, 51 pura vediesi ne l’ultimo artista.
query.result: 49 But the citizenry, which is now mixed 50 with people from Campi, Certaldo, and Figline, 51 was seen to be pure in the humblest artisan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Oh quanto fora meglio esser vicine 53 quelle genti ch’io dico, e al Galluzzo 54 e a Trespiano aver vostro confine,
query.result: 52 Oh, how much better it would be if those people I speak of were closer, 53 and if your border were at Galluzzo 54 and Trespiano,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 che averle dentro e sostener lo puzzo 56 del villan d’Aguglion, di quel da Signa, 57 che già per barattare ha l’occhio aguzzo!
query.result: 55 than to have them inside and endure the stench 56 of the peasant from Aguglione, of the one from Signa, 57 who already has a sharp eye for bartering!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
58 Se la gente ch’al mondo più traligna 59 non fosse stata a Cesare noverca, 60 ma come madre a suo figlio benigna,
query.result: 58 If the people who are most degenerate in the world 59 had not been a stepmother to Caesar, 60 but rather a kind mother to her son,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 tal fatto è fiorentino e cambia e merca, 62 che si sarebbe vòlto a Simifonti, 63 là dove andava l’avolo a la cerca;

Please translate each line literally into English.
64 sariesi Montemurlo ancor de’ Conti; 65 sarieno i Cerchi nel piovier d’Acone, 66 e forse in Valdigrieve i Buondelmonti.

Please translate each line literally into English.
67 Sempre la confusion de le persone 68 principio fu del mal de la cittade, 69 come del vostro il cibo che s’appone;

Please translate each line literally into English.
70 e cieco toro più avaccio cade 71 che cieco agnello; e molte volte taglia 72 più e meglio una che le cinque spade.
query.result: 70 and a blind bull falls more quickly 71 than a blind lamb; and many times one sword 72 cuts more and better than five.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
73 Se tu riguardi Luni e Orbisaglia 74 come sono ite, e come se ne vanno 75 di retro ad esse Chiusi e Sinigaglia,
query.result: 73 If you consider Luni and Urbisaglia, 74 how they have fared, and how Chiusi and Sinigaglia 75 are following them into decline,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 udir come le schiatte si disfanno 77 non ti parrà nova cosa né forte, 78 poscia che le cittadi termine hanno.
query.result: 76 hearing how lineages come to an end 77 will not seem strange or difficult to you, 78 since cities have their limits.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Le vostre cose tutte hanno lor morte, 80 sì come voi; ma celasi in alcuna 81 che dura molto, e le vite son corte.
query.result: 79 All your things have their death, 80 just like you; but it is hidden in some things 81 that last a long time, and lives are short.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
82 E come ’l volger del ciel de la luna 83 cuopre e discuopre i liti sanza posa, 84 così fa di Fiorenza la Fortuna:
query.result: 82 And just as the turning of the moon in the sky 83 covers and uncovers the shores without pause, 84 so does Fortune do to Florence:

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
85 per che non dee parer mirabil cosa 86 ciò ch’io dirò de li alti Fiorentini 87 onde è la fama nel tempo nascosa.
query.result: 85 therefore it should not seem a wondrous thing 86 what I will say about the noble Florentines 87 whose fame is hidden in time.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
88 Io vidi li Ughi e vidi i Catellini, 89 Filippi, Greci, Ormanni e Alberichi, 90 già nel calare, illustri cittadini;

Please translate each line literally into English.
91 e vidi così grandi come antichi, 92 con quel de la Sannella, quel de l’Arca, 93 e Soldanieri e Ardinghi e Bostichi.
query.result: 91 and I saw some as great as they were ancient, 92 with the one from the Sannella, the one from the Arca, 93 and the Soldanieri, the Ardinghi, and the Bostichi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 Sovra la porta ch’al presente è carca 95 di nova fellonia di tanto peso 96 che tosto fia iattura de la barca,
query.result: 94 Above the gate that is now burdened 95 with new felony of such weight 96 that it will soon be the boat’s undoing,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 erano i Ravignani, ond’ è disceso 98 il conte Guido e qualunque del nome 99 de l’alto Bellincione ha poscia preso.
query.result: 97 were the Ravignani, from whom are descended 98 Count Guido and whoever has since taken the name 99 of the noble Bellincione.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 Quel de la Pressa sapeva già come 101 regger si vuole, e avea Galigaio 102 dorata in casa sua già l’elsa e ’l pome.
query.result: 100 The one from the Pressa already knew how 101 one must rule, and Galigaio 102 already had the hilt and pommel gilded in his house.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
103 Grand’ era già la colonna del Vaio, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti e Barucci 105 e Galli e quei ch’arrossan per lo staio.
query.result: 103 The column of the Vaio was already great, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti, and Barucci, 105 and Galli and those who blush for the bushel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Lo ceppo di che nacquero i Calfucci 107 era già grande, e già eran tratti 108 a le curule Sizii e Arrigucci.
query.result: 106 The stump from which the Calfucci were born 107 was already large, and already had been drawn 108 to the curule Sizii and Arrigucci.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Oh quali io vidi quei che son disfatti 110 per lor superbia! e le palle de l’oro 111 fiorian Fiorenza in tutt’ i suoi gran fatti.
query.result: 109 Oh, how I saw those who are undone 110 through their pride! And the golden balls 111 made Florence flourish in all its great deeds.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 Così facieno i padri di coloro 113 che, sempre che la vostra chiesa vaca, 114 si fanno grassi stando a consistoro.
query.result: 112 Thus did the fathers of those who, 113 whenever your church is vacant, 114 grow fat while sitting in consistory.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
115 L’oltracotata schiatta che s’indraca 116 dietro a chi fugge, e a chi mostra ’l dente 117 o ver la borsa, com’ agnel si placa,
query.result: 115 The overweening lineage that bristles 116 at whoever flees, and toward whoever shows his teeth 117 or his purse, is appeased like a lamb,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 già venìa sù, ma di picciola gente; 119 sì che non piacque ad Ubertin Donato 120 che poï il suocero il fé lor parente.

Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Già era ’l Caponsacco nel mercato 122 disceso giù da Fiesole, e già era 123 buon cittadino Giuda e Infangato.
query.result: 121 Already the Caponsacco had come down 122 from Fiesole to the market, and already 123 Giuda and Infangato were good citizens.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
124 Io dirò cosa incredibile e vera: 125 nel picciol cerchio s’entrava per porta 126 che si nomava da quei de la Pera.
query.result: 124 I will tell something incredible and true: 125 one entered the small circle through a gate 126 that was named after those of the Pera.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Ciascun che de la bella insegna porta 128 del gran barone il cui nome e ’l cui pregio 129 la festa di Tommaso riconforta,
query.result: 127 Everyone who bears the fair ensign 128 of the great baron whose name and whose worth 129 the feast of Thomas comforts,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 da esso ebbe milizia e privilegio; 131 avvegna che con popol si rauni 132 oggi colui che la fascia col fregio.

Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Già eran Gualterotti e Importuni; 134 e ancor saria Borgo più quïeto, 135 se di novi vicin fosser digiuni.

Please translate each line literally into English.
136 La casa di che nacque il vostro fleto, 137 per lo giusto disdegno che v’ha morti 138 e puose fine al vostro viver lieto,
query.result: 136 The house from which your weeping sprang, 137 through the just disdain that has killed you 138 and put an end to your happy life,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
139 era onorata, essa e suoi consorti: 140 o Buondelmonte, quanto mal fuggisti 141 le nozze süe per li altrui conforti!
query.result: 139 was honored, it and its kin: 140 O Buondelmonte, how badly you shunned 141 his marriage at the urging of others!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
142 Molti sarebber lieti, che son tristi, 143 se Dio t’avesse conceduto ad Ema 144 la prima volta ch’a città venisti.
query.result: 142 Many who are sad would be joyful, 143 if God had granted you to the Ema 144 the first time you came to the city.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
145 Ma conveniesi a quella pietra scema 146 che guarda ’l ponte, che Fiorenza fesse 147 vittima ne la sua pace postrema.
query.result: 145 But it is fitting for that defective stone 146 that overlooks the bridge, that Florence should make 147 a victim of it in its final peace.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
148 Con queste genti, e con altre con esse, 149 vid’ io Fiorenza in sì fatto riposo, 150 che non avea cagione onde piangesse.
query.result: 148 With these people, and with others with them, 149 I saw Florence in such a state of repose, 150 that it had no cause to weep.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
151 Con queste genti vid’io glorïoso 152 e giusto il popol suo, tanto che ’l giglio 153 non era ad asta mai posto a ritroso,
query.result: 151 With these people I saw its people glorious 152 and just, so much so that the lily 153 was never set upside down on a lance,

154 né per divisïon fatto vermiglio».
query.result: 154 nor made red by division.
